channel.title: Help with science,
channel.description:
:) I HAD Keyword HAD 55 but not i'm down to 21 anyone think they can help me
1: Stomach cells secreting gastric junce in response to the presence of food provide an example of an involuntary action. True False
2: Although breathing is basically involuntary, it can be modified by conscious control. True False
3: Nerve cells have cytoplasm, but no nuclei. True False
4: A nreve cell receives incoming messages on threadlike projections called dendrites. True False
5: Some nerve cells have nerve fibers that are two to three feet long. True False
6: A nerve message can be conducted along a motor nerve fiber in either direction. True False
7: Nerves are made up entirely of nerve fibers or axons. True False
8: Nerve messages from motor nerve cells control the actions of muscles. True False
9: The cerebellum is the memory center of the human brain. True False
10: Conscious acts, such as speaking and singing are controlled by the medulla of the brain. True False
11: The cranial nerves that enable us to see, hear, and taste connect directly to the brain. True False
12: When damaged, nerve tissue is less likely to repair itself than other body tissues. True False
13: The pupil of the eye is really an opening through which light enters the eye. True False
14: The colored part of the eye functions to focus images on the retina. True False
15: Nearsightedness is caused by an abnormal shape of the eyeball. True False
16: Vibrations of the eardrum are carried to the sensitive part of the ear by the Eustachian tube. True False
17: The hearing center of the inner ear is a gas-filled structure. True False
18: Microorganisms may reach the ear through the blood. True False
19: When you feel too wearm and decide to move to a cooler place, this act is called a reflex. True False
20: A habit is a learned act that has become largely or wholly automatic. True False
21: If a person has great intelligence, that means they also have a great deal of knowledge. True False

item.title: Help with science,
item.dc:creator: @Friday13th Friday13th
item.description:
@Friday13th wrote:

1: Stomach cells secreting gastric junce in response to the presence of food provide an example of an involuntary action.
this one is not so easy to answer.
first of all the HCl is produced by the stomac/gaster all the time. hormons from the duodenum also enhac the production of the enzymes. anyway i think its True ( but not fully )
2: Although breathing is basically involuntary, it can be modified by conscious control.
lol yes
3: Nerve cells have cytoplasm, but no nuclei.
false -> only human red blood cells dont have an nuclei
4: A nreve cell receives incoming messages on threadlike projections called dendrites.
true ... but not always. The contact an be also aksonal-aksonal ( I dont know how do you write it in english ) in such situation the impules will be stopt. but yes major messeages income to dendrites
5: Some nerve cells have nerve fibers that are two to three feet long.
lol ... how mutch is feet long ? in cm ? I hate your non-metric system:) anyway know that nerve cells are the longes in our body. form the spinal cord down to your foot
6: A nerve message can be conducted along a motor nerve fiber in either direction.
False ... sorry but nerves dont conduct messages in 2 ways
7: Nerves are made up entirely of nerve fibers or axons.
Flase -... the axons are the most bigest part but there other parts of the cell
8: Nerve messages from motor nerve cells control the actions of muscles.
It should be motoric ( I gues ) ... anyway the receptor get the impulse, withc is led to the spinal cord and from there by the motoric cells to the muscels
9: The cerebellum is the memory center of the human brain.
false... cerebellum is the oldest part of the human brain. It is responsible for all the basic actions. The memory is located in the front lobes.
10: Conscious acts, such as speaking and singing are controlled by the medulla of the brain.
false --... medulla is responsible for breating ( mostly )
11: The cranial nerves that enable us to see, hear, and taste connect directly to the brain.
true
12: When damaged, nerve tissue is less likely to repair itself than other body tissues.
true
13: The pupil of the eye is really an opening through which light enters the eye.
true ... lol
14: The colored part of the eye functions to focus images on the retina.
false. its funcion is to adjust the brightnes of the light that enters the eye
15: Nearsightedness is caused by an abnormal shape of the eyeball.
true... in a way
16: Vibrations of the eardrum are carried to the sensitive part of the ear by the Eustachian tube.
false... It connects the ear with the nosal part of the throat ( throat has 3 parts )
17: The hearing center of the inner ear is a gas-filled structure.
False ... fluid
18: Microorganisms may reach the ear through the blood.
True... but not always. It all depends about witch part of the ear they are asking
19: When you feel too wearm and decide to move to a cooler place, this act is called a reflex.
False.
20: A habit is a learned act that has become largely or wholly automatic.
True... in a way
21: If a person has great intelligence, that means they also have a great deal of knowledge.
False

Read full topic

item.title: Help with science,
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

You're lucky Im bored lol...

1.T
2.T
3.F (They do have nuclei...)
4.T
5.T
6.F (Not sure, but i think there are separate motor neurons - one for each direction)
7.F (Well they cant be if they have a nucleus can they..?)
8.T
9.T
10.F (The medulla controlls involantary acts..)
11.T
12.T
13.T
14.F (The colored part of the eye is muscle, which controlls the size of the pupil)
15.T
16.F (It connects the ear with the back of the throat doesnt it?)
17.F (Its fluid filled)
18.T (Im pretty sure...not 100% though)
19.F (Its a volantary thing...you have to consciously do it...it doesnt just 'happen)
20.T
21.F (Wat the..this is a random question...Intelligence is ABLILITY, knowledge is- well - knowledge)

Not sure about some of them, but Id say most are right.

Read full topic
